text:
Hi, has anyone ever had calls/mentorship from CMOs and generally, more experienced marketing leaders? How do your agendas look like? Tackling specific problems, or overview of how to optimise your work processes? I realise it's case by case, but I'm trying to balance out what's good for me and for the company. I realise I'll probably get general answers if any, but anything will be appreciated, really. I just don't want to waste the CMOs time. 

Would love to get some thoughts here on how you approached similar opportunity. :fire: :the_horns:

elements.text:
Hi, has anyone ever had calls/mentorship from CMOs and generally, more experienced marketing leaders? How do your agendas look like? Tackling specific problems, or overview of how to optimise your work processes? I realise it's case by case, but I'm trying to balance out what's good for me and for the company. I realise I'll probably get general answers if any, but anything will be appreciated, really. I just don't want to waste the CMOs time. 

Would love to get some thoughts here on how you approached similar opportunity.

text:
Optimizing work processes is probably a bit too tactical for most leaders. Depending on their interests and experience, I would recommend chatting with them about:
• Managing up to leadership/board of directors
• Budget
• Messaging
• Go-to-market strategy for new products, verticals, geographies
• Developing leadership skills to progress toward leadership roles

elements.text: Optimizing work processes is probably a bit too tactical for most leaders. Depending on their interests and experience, I would recommend chatting with them about:

Messaging
Go-to-market strategy for new products, verticals, geographies
Developing leadership skills to progress toward leadership roles

text: Now in two different content roles I've had, I've found myself at the center of planning cross-team marketing campaigns. Has anyone experienced this or seen this happen elsewhere in a way that evolves into a more defined role around both leading content strategy and campaigns/more of a brand-centric role? Figuring out if I try to set some guard rails around my content role or lean into the direction and pursue/pitch this kind of hybrid role at some point. Ty!

elements.text: Now in two different content roles I've had, I've found myself at the center of planning cross-team marketing campaigns. Has anyone experienced this or seen this happen elsewhere in a way that evolves into a more defined role around both leading content strategy and campaigns/more of a brand-centric role? Figuring out if I try to set some guard rails around my content role or lean into the direction and pursue/pitch this kind of hybrid role at some point. Ty!

text: Hi Liz, can you give an example of what you mean by cross-team marketing campaigns?

elements.text: Hi Liz, can you give an example of what you mean by cross-team marketing campaigns?

text: Hey <@UJFCA8FAR>, +1 to Anton’s question—can you give an example? I think I know what you mean but before I answer I want some more context :wink:

elements.text: Hey
, +1 to Anton’s question—can you give an example? I think I know what you mean but before I answer I want some more context

text: Sure thing - example = setting the framework for the campaign - goals, theme/tagline, approach (e.g., positioning products/company as a solution for career changes during pandemic) + coordinating execution across channels (content, email, social, paid, etc.). Some work with freelance designer to develop visual theme and copywriter to develop messaging guide. So content of course driven by me anyways, plus translating content to channels + helping brainstorm other channel-specific executions

elements.text: Sure thing - example = setting the framework for the campaign - goals, theme/tagline, approach (e.g., positioning products/company as a solution for career changes during pandemic) + coordinating execution across channels (content, email, social, paid, etc.). So content of course driven by me anyways, plus translating content to channels + helping brainstorm other channel-specific executions

text: okay, get it. it seems like a move from content strategist to more of a brand strategist/brand lead; or, staying away from job titles, it looks like a move from a narrower to a wider hybrid role

elements.text: okay, get it. it seems like a move from content strategist to more of a brand strategist/brand lead; or, staying away from job titles, it looks like a move from a narrower to a wider hybrid role

text: I’ve seen it happen—it’s happening where I work, actually!, that the former content strategist pivoted into becoming a marketing strategist within the brand team

elements.text: I’ve seen it happen—it’s happening where I work, actually!, that the former content strategist pivoted into becoming a marketing strategist within the brand team

text: yes! well put. Interesting - were they still involved with content post-pivot? Or it was a totally new/separate role with a backfill for content?

elements.text: yes! well put. Interesting - were they still involved with content post-pivot? Or it was a totally new/separate role with a backfill for content?

text: Also, the senior content editor (moi!) pivoted into being a senior brand editor that works across multiple marketing campaigns at the same time as the content strategist-who-is-now-a-marketing-strategist [for example, I just finished working on a couple of paid campaigns where before I was 100% on non-paid]. So it’s a definite lateral move BUT it’s becoming very clear to me that, the more I get involved in this, the less time I have to be an actual practitioner. Basically, now that it’s happening, you have two people who jointly grew their role from content to brand—and our role(s) will need backfilling, yes, because we’re now short on people doing-the-doing of content!

elements.text: Also, the senior content editor (moi!) pivoted into being a senior brand editor that works across multiple marketing campaigns at the same time as the content strategist-who-is-now-a-marketing-strategist [for example, I just finished working on a couple of paid campaigns where before I was 100% on non-paid]. So it’s a definite lateral move BUT it’s becoming very clear to me that, the more I get involved in this, the less time I have to be an actual practitioner. Basically, now that it’s happening, you have two people who jointly grew their role from content to brand—and our role(s) will need backfilling, yes, because we’re now short on people doing-the-doing of content!

text: To me, this has been a great opportunity to expand outside of the boundaries of a ‘content editor’ role—I guess the question for you is: is this something that you’d be interested in, moving forward? :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: To me, this has been a great opportunity to expand outside of the boundaries of a ‘content editor’ role—I guess the question for you is: is this something that you’d be interested in, moving forward?

text: I love that! Andd ohh yes, I am in the same struggle of figuring out expanding the people doing-the-doing of content as I expand into these other more strategic areas. Have to keep reminding myself me just adding more work to my pile is not the real solution :upside_down_face: definitely interested in a similar type of expansion. How did you/the content strategist move into these broader roles - was it a pathway already or easily defined within the company or were you more involved in pitching/scoping yourself?

text: (thank you for this great advice/sharing of experience!)

elements.text: (thank you for this great advice/sharing of experience!)

text: We both pitched our proposed roles to the Marketing Leadership team—in my particular case, having been on the team for 3+ years, I figured I would be much more helpful/impactful in a Brand position where I could influence/shape a larger amount of deliverables. The same was true for the Strategist—the two of us used to be a 2-person content team… and now, we have both moved into a new Brand team that was kind of ‘invented’ because of our persuasive argument :wink:

elements.text: We both pitched our proposed roles to the Marketing Leadership team—in my particular case, having been on the team for 3+ years, I figured I would be much more helpful/impactful in a Brand position where I could influence/shape a larger amount of deliverables. The same was true for the Strategist—the two of us used to be a 2-person content team… and now, we have both moved into a new Brand team that was kind of ‘invented’ because of our persuasive argument

text: So I guess in a sense it all depends on how receptive your company is + how persuasive you are in making the point that your skills are better utilised if you do a, b, _and also_ c instead of ‘just’ doing a and b

elements.text: So I guess in a sense it all depends on how receptive your company is + how persuasive you are in making the point that your skills are better utilised if you do a, b,
and also
c instead of ‘just’ doing a and b

text:
Oh boy, that's a lot of great insight from <@U017WRJTKF1>. I've experience a similar situation in my last two roles and I agree that it depends on how receptive your leadership is to this kind of change.

I also suggest that you set up some resourcing boundaries with your role in order to show that there's a need to grow the team and/or shift your position. If you're going above and beyond your current role, and your leadership sees that you're able to handle the workload without them needing to spend extra $$ to hire someone else or promote you, then you run the risk of getting stuck doing more or doing it all. That may or may not be the case in your company, but it's happened to me in the past and I've had to learn the hard way to set strict limits to what I can do with my given role/time/energy versus what I'm being asked to do.

elements.text: Oh boy, that's a lot of great insight from

. I've experience a similar situation in my last two roles and I agree that it depends on how receptive your leadership is to this kind of change.

I also suggest that you set up some resourcing boundaries with your role in order to show that there's a need to grow the team and/or shift your position. If you're going above and beyond your current role, and your leadership sees that you're able to handle the workload without them needing to spend extra $$ to hire someone else or promote you, then you run the risk of getting stuck doing more or doing it all. That may or may not be the case in your company, but it's happened to me in the past and I've had to learn the hard way to set strict limits to what I can do with my given role/time/energy versus what I'm being asked to do.

text: Great point <@UMFSZ8JHL> - I did have that scope creep in my previous position and have tried to be more careful in my current role while figuring out what an expansion could look like, a tricky balance

text: <@UJFCA8FAR> this is exactly the kind of work that set me up to take on broader/leadership roles on the marketing team. In order for this to work, you definitely need a #2 person doing content to pick up the slack for the amount of project management and team leadership you’re taking on, if you don’t already have that person.

text: I often weighted what I said no to off of how it aligns with my personal long-term goals. For instance, I use to (<-- key word here) to sit on multiple non-profit boards, all of which required different aspects of my time. Many were in the education space, which is a path I am highly interested in, but required meeting during school hours (conflict with my day job). So, for the ones I kept, they had to fit “my time, my scope, my interest.” Can I do this in the off-hours? How does it fit the scope of where I want to go? Is this interesting to me? If I checked all three boxes, I also weighted “does this open me up to new opportunities?” For some, that was the differentiator - not all opened my up to where I wanted to go in the long run; others did.
